utterance: David Kwabi: Uh yeah, I am. So I mentioned uh this uh work on sort of electrochemical pH swing as a way of doing CO2 separation. Um I'd say that the well, a couple of things maybe, but in terms of the the one minute sort of idea or thing I'm thinking about, um you know one thing I'll just throw out there is sort of thinking about ways of building sort of multifunctional uh either interfaces or materials that that sort of satisfy a number of the requirements that you need for CO2 separation especially from air. So um you know so you you if you're doing CO2 capture from air you want something that's say oxygen that's not uh sort of sensitive to oxygen. Um you also want ideally something that's non-volatile so if you're doing this in an organic solvent you're going to have issues with solvent loss. Um and then you want something that's um redox active or that's sort of responds to an electric field or a potential and so captures CO2 in one state and then releases it in another. And I'm curious as to whether it it makes any sense and you know maybe in in typically what you would do is you pick the solvent and then you pick the active material and you sort of mix the two together you know you sort of build your system from there. Um I'm curious whether it makes sense to also think about trying to do or or make sort of multifunctional sorbents that would fulfill a number of these requirements simultaneously. So for example you start with uh like an ionic liquid for example which would not where you wouldn't have as much of an issue with uh volatility and that is sort of your backbone and then you sort of build on top of that some sort of functionality or something either redox active or electric field responsive that does your that does sort of the switching uh the sort of CO2 reversible CO2 binding and release component. So I'm just sort of that's sort of what I'm thinking about um is whether you could build these sort of chemical uh these these sort of new material systems. And then you you you know you put that in like a reactor um and one could then think about how effective it actually works in a in a real system but yeah that's that's one thought.

utterance: Phill Milner: Yeah that's what I was thinking was so the you know from what I've seen you know from my surveying the literature I don't know it that well but a lot of it is focused on that I've seen is quinones because when you reduce them they make uh you know we can think of the classic redox couple of quinone hydroquinone but it goes through the double O minus compound which is now nucleophilic which can attack CO2 to make a carbonate and if you then oxidize it back it will go back to the quinone which is not nucleophilic. utterance: Jenny Yang: So uh we've we're we're actually writing a review on the topic. So the best quinone that the delta K EQ is 10 to the 15. So that's like staggering right it's easily enough to capture from air. Um but that one has a reduction potential of minus 1.7 or 0.8. And so if we plot the log of um the binding constant versus the redox potential we get a linear free energy relationship which basically just means that as we go more negative we bind better but obviously more negative means more oxygen sensitive. And so we're basically trying to find ways to get off that line uh so to speak right um so basically try to find ways to improve the nucleophilicity uh without um improving the potential. utterance: Jenny Yang: I have a question for related to what you were saying about scale. And I know some of you guys work with flow batteries too, which is probably related. Is there an optimal scale at which to run these electrochemical processes and is it can you can you scale it down without any loss indefinitely? Like what's what's what what sizes matter?

annotations.Ask Question: Jenny Yang is requesting information or clarification on the scalability of electrochemical processes and if they can be scaled down without loss.
annotations.Develop Idea: She minimally expands on her question by referencing flow batteries as a related area.

utterance: Fik Brushett: It depends on the process a little bit and it depends upon where your cost is in the process. So for example, you could sort of think of it as flow batteries are an easy example because you can separate power and energy and so if you want an energy intensive application, the cost is dominated by what's in your tank. If you have a power dominant application it's dominated by what it costs you to make the reactor. In these kind of systems it's a bit different, right? And it would probably the way you'd want to think about it is throughput, right? So it's kind of what is the capital cost of your reactor and then how much CO2 can you put through it because that's how you're going to make money, right? And so that's how you should think about it. I mean capital cost is important because, you know, bankability, like someone's got to pay for the thing, right? And so if you think about like the first solar cells, they they kind of stunk, right? But they're still working and they're small and you can put them on your roof, right? And so, if for electrochemical systems you could build at that sort of scale, local residential scale, and that allows you to do a lot more learning as you go and it allows you also to make smaller products which means that there's less opportunities for for screw ups and a lot less money involved. For a lot of sort of, you know, the larger scale systems like I guess carbon engineering, I mean I think that system is is is pretty big in the base case and I don't know how many of them they've built. I'm not so I've seen a lot of pretty pictures but I don't know if I've actually seen a plant. And so there's some something about like well who's paying for this? How confident are you that this is going to work? Yada yada yada this kind of stuff, right? So I don't think electrochemical systems can be infinitely small for sure. But you could be a lot smaller than thermochemical systems and actually if you look at scaling analysis, thermochemical systems can beat out electrochemical systems at large enough scale, right? Just because of heat integration, we're really good at that. But at smaller scales the tables turn.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on existing ideas about the scalability and cost-effectiveness of electrochemical systems for CO2 capture, providing examples and reasoning.
